system: You are a resident physician tasked with writing a discharge summary letter of a patient from the patient's Electronic Health Records.
user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

This is an example of discharge summary letter:
Dear ___,

You came into hospital because you were getting more short of breath and your ankles were swollen.

A heart scan, called an echocardiogram, showed that your heart was not pumping as well as it should.

We started you on water tablets called Furosemide. They will stop fluid collecting in your legs and lungs.

Please take 2 Furosemide tablets (2 x 40 mg = 80 mg) each morning and weigh yourself each morning.

If your weight drops by more than 2 kg over the week, reduce the dose to 1 tablet per day.

We have asked your GP practice to see you in about 2 weeks' time. They will take a blood test to check your kidney function.

We will see you in 6 weeks' time in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.

You will receive an appointment letter in the post.

Sincerely,
____

Dear ___,

You presented to the hospital on March 1, 2024, with severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and shortness of breath. Upon admission, an electrocardiogram revealed an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), indicating an acute transmural myocardial infarction of the anterior wall. You underwent an immediate Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) with stent placement, following which you remained stable.

During your hospital stay, your troponin levels, which were initially elevated and peaked at 12 hours post-admission, showed a continuous decrease as observed from subsequent tests on March 2 and March 3. You experienced no recurrent chest pain, and your vital signs stabilized throughout your stay. You reported feeling better with effective pain management.

On March 2, 2024, you started on a beta-blocker, Metoprolol, administered at 50 mg twice daily, along with an ACE inhibitor, Lisinopril 10 mg once daily, and a statin at 40 mg daily for cholesterol management. You were also placed on Aspirin (325 mg once daily), Clopidogrel (75 mg once daily), IV Heparin (dose adjusted per protocol), and Nitroglycerin as needed for chest pain.

By the time of discharge on March 6, 2024, your condition showed significant improvement, and discharge plans were discussed on March 4, ensuring you received comprehensive medication instructions and a structured follow-up plan. You are scheduled for a follow-up appointment at the Cardiology outpatient clinic on March 20, 2024, to assess your recovery and manage medication adjustments.

As part of your ongoing treatment, it is important to adopt a heart-healthy diet, low in saturated fats, cholesterol, and sodium, while increasing the intake of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. A gradual reintroduction of physical activity is recommended, beginning with light walking, and aiming to build up to at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity per week. Immediate smoking cessation is advised, and you may consider nicotine replacement therapy and counseling for support. To aid stress management, explore activities such as mindfulness, yoga, or meditation, and seek professional assistance if necessary.

Should any new symptoms arise, or if existing symptoms worsen, please seek medical attention promptly.

We wish you a smooth recovery and look forward to seeing your progress at the upcoming follow-up.

Sincerely,

___
